Drop elaborate map override instructions

This system is still there if you need it, but these instructions were
more confusing than helpful.

Closes https://github.com/tpope/vim-dispatch/issues/236
Fix expansion of buffer by number

Set l# alongside v:lnum

This enables line number handling in a way that, unlike `=...`
expressions, is compatible with plain Vim.

    let b:dispatch = 'rspec %:s/$/\=exists("l#") ? ":".l# : "")/'

Assigning to a local variable with a hash symbol in the name isn't
normally allowed, so this is great for avoiding false positives as well
as style.  Older versions of Vim don't accept such variable names with
the l: prefix, so make sure you omit it.

I've also defined a backup variable in case further issues crop up with
the cool, cool name.
More robust parsing of embedded default tasks
Update installation instructions

Also run default dispatch on :0Start

This might get superseded by something more interesting later, so leave
it as unofficial and undocumented.

Add g` maps as alias for g'

This fits with the new :{range}Spawn mechanic.

Support combining default command with options

This lets you do `:Start -wait=always` and still use b:start.

Unify expansion

I was going to a great deal of trouble to apply `=...` expansion
separately for 'makeprg' so that QuickFixCmdPre wouldn't get an
inaccurate picture of the command to run.  But I've decided that this
expansion is on the way out and it doesn't really matter if the
auto-command sees some weird syntax.

This also drops some support for experimental variations of that syntax
that were never officially supported.

I've been experiencing some weirdness and need a way to rule this out.

This has no effect on the current code base, but I have aspirations to
use the value in the future.

This is so I can later add line1 and line2 parameters and not burn

Skip automatic copen when height <= 0

copen and cwindow expect a positive number for the window height so we
can use the value 0 to state that the quickfix window should not be
opened or closed automatically
So when setting g:dispatch_quickfix_height to 0, `:Copen` updates the
quickfix list without opening the quickfix window and prevents the
quickfix window from opening on completion of a `:Dispatch` until the
next explicit `:copen`

Accept ++args

I modeled -dir= after :command, but ++dir= is more in line with typical
Vim commands, and in particular matches up with the new :terminal
command.  It's also distinct enough that we could potentially support it
for :Make.  For now, quietly support it as an alternative syntax.

Specify buffer specific task in 'errorformat'

This task is used for :.Make, :0Make, and as a penultimate fallback for
:Dispatch.

Allow forcing a :Make subcommand to use :Start

Say makeprg is lein, and you want to override `:Make repl` to call not
`:Dispatch lein repl` but rather `:Start lein repl`.  This change
enables achieving that with a special declaration in errorformat:

    setl errorformat+=%\\&terminal=%\\Crepl%\\>%.%#

The pattern uses Vim's peculiar scanf variant documented under the
errorformat help topic.  Note the use of %\C, because Vim is case
insensitive by default in this context.  The key name "terminal" is
meant to convey the underlying semantic: the command requires a
terminal, and should not be piped to a file.

I am experimentally providing this to help with "do what I mean", but it
goes against the spirit of :Make as a paper thin :make wrapper, so even
if it sticks around, I'll still be favoring dedicated commands like
:Console as the official interface.

Use default :Make task found in 'errorformat'

This is intended to let :Make run something useful by default for
commands like `rails` and `lein` that display usage information or
something equally worthless when called with no arguments.

This works by looking for `%\&default=...` in 'errorformat.  The `%\&`
prevents Vim from matching it to any error output.

iTerm 3 compatability (#174)

iTerm 3 introduced breaking changes to the AppleScript api, mentioned
here https://www.iterm2.com/version3.html and here
https://www.iterm2.com/documentation-scripting.html. This allows the
iTerm dispatcher to work with either the version 2 or version 3 api.

Fix documentation for the :Dispatch command (#181)

In the documentation of `:Dispatch` there is an inconsistency: the
argument name is `{program}`, but in the documentation body there is a
reference to `{command}` which is unclear. This removes the
inconsistency and renames `{command}` to `{program}` in the
documentation body.

On UNIX, an exception is made for interrupts, exit status 130.  On

Expand `=expr` in arguments

The primary use case here is to set a dynamic default in b:dispatch,
based on the current line number or some other criteria.  :FocusDispatch
has changed to show the raw backtick expressions without a count and the
expansions if a count is given.

In addition to `=expr`, there is also `+=expr`, which expands only with
a line number, and `-=expr`, which expands only without one.  In all
three, v:lnum is set to the line number given or zero.

Fix pid functions with cygwin shells

The actually problem is that vim automatically set &shellquote='"' when
&shell is some kind of posix-like shells. When &shellquote is '"',
writing double quotes in the command passed to system() would cause the
command to be misinterpreted, and producing the weird error as reported
in #108.  The solution is to detect whether shellquote is set to double
quote, and alter the sent command accordingly.

Note that this issue would not affect default windows cmd shell, thus
the command should only be altered when *sh shells are used.

Fixes #108.

^[[2K^[[0G means "clear line and move to the first column". They clutter up the

Add potential future alternatives to <lnum>

<line1> and <line2> are used by Vim in command definitions, and would
probably be a better alternative to inventing our own <lnum>.

Don't fire modelines quickfix autocommands

Modelines can trigger the FileType event, which can in turn clobber our
'errorformat'.

Allow :0Dispatch to bypass focus

Really both focusing and default tasks belong in separate plugins, but
until that happens, provide a way to override the focus with the buffer
default.

One can also use 2:Dispatch, which is convenient with a map.

output is identical to the other adapters.

Remove catch-all ignore from error format

Since :Make, unlike :make, never shows you the original output, it makes
sense to be less aggressive in filtering out unrecognized lines.
Previously this would have had the downside of opening the quickfix
window for uneventful runs, but recent commits rectify this.

^[[K is an escape code that means "clear to end of line", and should be
a no-op in absence of other cursor movement.

clever use of filename-modifiers, you can generally make a default that
works both ways.  Example:

    let b:dispatch = 'rspec %<lnum>:s?^?:?'

Fix loading of errors on synchronous build

Don't open quickfix after synchronous dispatch

If another plugin has wrapped :Make in a construct that changes and
restores the current directory, opening the quickfix after a synchronous
make means restoring the directory for the wrong window.  Running
synchronously is already a vastly different experience than the other
adapters, so I think an additional small inconsistency is acceptable
price to pay for rectifying this behavior.

References #28.

Allow delegating to a Vim command in default dispatch

Not convinced this is anything but trouble, but the idea is that
sometimes you'd rather let another plugin handle the :Dispatch details
(e.g., rails.vim's :Rake) or just do something else entirely (e.g.,
scriptease.vim's :Runtime).  This works with :FocusDispatch too, but
note that :FocusDispatch :Rake runs :Rake literally, which is probably
not what you want if you switch buffers.
